item.title: Inside Iran’s Preparation for War and Plans for Survival
item.description: Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has entrusted Ali Larijani, the top national security official, to ensure the Islamic Republic endures possible war and assassination.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ali Larijani, the secretary of the Supreme National Security Council of Iran, in May 2024.

item.title: Iran’s Students Hold Anti-Regime Protests as Universities Reopen
item.description: Students helped grow initial protests into a national movement crushed by the government. As the new semester began, they chanted and marched again.
item.dc:creator: Leily Nikounazar, Pranav Baskar and Devon Lum
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathering at Amirkabir University in Tehran, in an image from a social media post that was verified by The New York Times.

item.title: At Least 10 Killed in Lebanon, Officials Say, After Israel Strikes Hezbollah
item.description: The Lebanese militant group said eight of its members were among those killed late Friday. The attacks threaten to further destabilize an already tenuous cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Bilal Hussein/Associated Press
item.media:description: Coffins draped in fabric bearing the symbol of Hezbollah are carried through the village of Nabi Sheet, eastern Lebanon, on Saturday.

item.title: Why Attacking Iran Could Be Riskier Than Capturing Maduro
item.description: Iran’s extensive military abilities and network of regional proxies could draw the United States into a prolonged conflict.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Samuel Granados
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Palestinian-American Teenager Killed in West Bank Is Laid to Rest
item.description: Nasrallah Abu Siyam, 19, was shot dead by an Israeli settler, according to a witness and Palestinian health officials, amid rising violent settler attacks in the Israeli-occupied territory.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Fatima AbdulKarim
item.media:credit: John Wessels/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The funeral of Nasrallah Abu Siyam, 19, in Mukhmas, a village in the West Bank, on Thursday, a day after he was killed.

item.title: Iran Says U.S. Has Not Asked It to Stop Enriching Uranium
item.description: The comments by Iran’s foreign minister on Friday contradicted the Trump administration’s position.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:credit: Martial Trezzini/Keystone, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Abbas Araghchi, the foreign minister of Iran, at the United Nations office in Geneva. The United States and Iran have been in Switzerland negotiating a nuclear deal this week.

item.title: As Trump Considers Second Iran Attack, It Could Be Deadlier Than the First
item.description: Within days of the U.S. strikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities last year, all sides agreed to a cease-fire. This time could be different.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A missile display at a celebration in Tehran this month.

item.title: A Makeup Ban in Syria for Women in Government and Public Sector Stirs Outrage
item.description: A provincial governor wants to prohibit women in government and public sector jobs from wearing makeup, stirring outrage and many, many memes.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women spending time at a cafe in Latakia, Syria, in May.

item.title: As Trump Weighs Iran Strikes, He Declines to Make Clear Case for Why
item.description: Rarely in modern times has the United States prepared to conduct a major act of war with so little explanation or public debate.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump speaking at the inaugural Board of Peace meeting in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: British Couple Held in Iran Is Sentenced to 10 Years in Prison, Family Says
item.description: Craig and Lindsay Foreman were arrested last year during a motorcycle tour around the world. Their relatives and the British government have rejected Iranian charges of “security crimes.”
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:credit: via Agence France-Presse/Getty Images
item.media:description: Craig and Lindsay Foreman, who have been sentenced to 10 years in prison in Iran, in a photograph released by their family.

item.title: Trump Considers Building a Military Base in Gaza as Peace Plans Clash With Reality
item.description: Israeli strikes on Gaza have killed about 600 people since a cease-fire began, according to health officials in the territory. Many displaced Palestinians are still living in tents. And there are some 60 million tons of war debris to be cleared.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner, Adam Rasgon, Aaron Boxerman, Natan Odenheimer and Saher Alghorra
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times

item.title: Israel’s Actions Questioned at Security Council Meeting
item.description: Amid criticism over the board’s structure and broad mandate, the U.S. ambassador to the U.N. defended the board, saying “a new way” was needed to address the situation in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael Waltz, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, at the Security Council last month. Mr. Waltz said President Trump’s Board of Peace planned to pledge $5 billion to the reconstruction and rehabilitation of Gaza.

item.title: As Trump Weighs Possible Iran Strikes, U.S. Military Moves Into Place
item.description: President Trump has given no indication that he has made a decision about how to proceed, as diplomatic talks continue.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jonathan Klein/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The U.S.S. Gerald R. Ford aircraft carrier, seen here in the North Sea last year, is making its way toward the Middle East.

item.title: At These Gaza Schools, ‘Peace Building’ Is Part of the Curriculum
item.description: A fast-growing network of private schools, the brainchild of a North Carolina neurosurgeon, is teaching 9,000 war orphans and other needy Palestinian youngsters.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger, Bilal Shbair and Saher Alghorra
item.media:description: Students lining up to enter a classroom at an Academy of Hope school in Deir al-Balah, in the central Gaza Strip, this month.

item.title: Power Shift in Syria Upends an Archipelago for ISIS Prisoners
item.description: America’s Kurdish allies oversaw two dozen sites holding thousands of members of the terrorist group and their families. Their withdrawal has left the system in chaos.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Hussam Hammoud and Nanna Heitmann
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Bets on Diplomacy Without Diplomats
item.description: President Trump’s most trusted envoys, Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, are at the center of the Iran and Ukraine negotiations.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Nathan Howard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner in Israel last October.

item.title: Trump’s ‘Board of Peace’ Presses Hamas on Disarmament, Officials Say
item.description: The direct talks last week came as officials urgently try to find a breakthrough on the issue of Hamas’s weapons, fearing the cease-fire in Gaza could collapse.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hamas militants searching for the bodies of remaining hostages north of Gaza City, in December.

item.title: Iranians Mourn Slain Protesters With ‘Revolutionary Rage’
item.description: The authorities moved to suppress shows of defiance at ceremonies commemorating 40 days since the death of protesters.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Leily Nikounazar, Sanjana Varghese and Jon Hazell
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Obtained by The New York Times

item.title: Iran Holds Exercises in Strait of Hormuz After Trump Threatens Military Action
item.description: The day before nuclear talks were set to resume, Iran conducted live drills in the Strait of Hormuz, a strategic waterway for oil and gas shipments.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:credit: Nicolas Economou/Reuters
item.media:description: The island of Qeshm, in the Strait of Hormuz. The strait is a key shipping lane for oil and gas and connects the Persian Gulf to the open ocean.

item.title: Syrian Army Crosses New Threshold With Advances in Kurdish Regions
item.description: The advance of the Syrian Army into Kurdish regions could put nearly all the country under one authority. But it ends a dream of autonomy for ethnic Kurds.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Hussam Hammoud and Nanna Heitmann
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: The Syrian Army has moved into vast new regions, seeking to erase the largest fissure left from the civil war.

item.title: Rage. Grief. Anxiety. The New Mood in Iran.
item.description: In the aftermath of another wave of antigovernment unrest, Iran is gripped by a mood of collective grief and uncertainty about the future.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Vahid Salemi/Associated Press
item.media:description: A billboard showing the current supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, alongside the Islamic Republic’s founding leader, in Tehran, Iran, last month.

item.title: Trump’s Stinging Attack on Israel’s President Touches a Nerve
item.description: President Trump called President Isaac Herzog of Israel “disgraceful” because he has not yet pardoned Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in his corruption trial.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump with Israel’s president, Isaac Herzog, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at Ben Gurion Airport in October.

item.title: Iran Protester Dies in Custody, Raising Fears of Execution
item.description: Rights groups are investigating the death of Ali Rahbar as a potential extrajudicial killing. Iran denies executions have taken place.
item.dc:creator: Sanam Mahoozi and Erika Solomon
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
